title: Kim Kardashian calls for Making a Murderer’s Brendan Dassey to be pardoned

Kim Kardashian has called for Making a Murderer’s Brendan Dassey to be pardoned.

The 29-year-old Dassey was convicted of rape and murder when he was in his teens and is currently serving a life sentence at a Wisconsin prison, and will be eligible for parole in 2048.

Reality star Kim has thrown her weight behind the cause, publicly showing support for his case and the campaign to release him.

The mum-of-four, who is a massive advocate for prison reform, has now joined the calls for Wisconsin’s governor to either a pardon or commutation of Dassey’s life sentence.

(Image: Ron Sachs/CNP/AdMedia / SplashNews.com)

Taking to Twitter , the star shared Dassey’s handwritten letter to Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers to her 62 million followers.

Directly addressing the governor, Kim captioned the post: “Please @GovEvers Read this letter."

Dassey's letter says: “I am writing to ask for a pardon because I am innocent and want to go home.

“If I would get to go home, I would like to get a job involving video games.

"I would like to help take care of my mom and one day have a son and a daughter of my own.

"I would name my daughter Grace and my son Mizar which is the name of a star in the big dipper.”

Alongside the letter, Kim shared a link to an episode of the podcast “Wrongful Conviction with Jason Flom” in which Dassey was interviewed, adding the hashtag #BringBrendanHome.

(Image: UGC)

The convict’s last appeal was not considered by the US Supreme Court, and it is highly unlikely he will be granted a pardon.

The governor’s rules to award a pardon are extremely strict and forbid anyone currently serving a prison sentence to be considered.

The rules state that all applicants must have completed their prison sentences, and any current prisoners will be rejected as ineligible.

The last pardon issued in Wisconsin was under Governor Tommy Thompson, who left office in 2001.

(Image: Irish Daily Mirror)

Dassey’s case has heralded international attention after he and his uncle Steven Avery were featured in the Netflix documentary Making A Murderer.

The show cast doubt on the legal process used to convict the pair.

Their case surrounds the murder of photographer Teresa Halbach, who disappeared in 2005 after visiting the Avery family salvage yard in Twin Rivers.

While Dassey was initially interviewed as a witness in the investigation into his uncle, in 2006 he was arrested and charged with being party to first-degree murder, sexual assault, and mutilation of a corpse.

Dassey was convicted in April 2007 after a nine-day trial and jailed for life.
